name: queryExecute
description: Executes a SQL query, returns the result.

params.description: Array or Struct of parameter values. When passing an array use ? as place holders. When passing a struct use :keyName where keyName is the name of the key in the structure corresponding to the parameter. The struct or array can be a struct with keys such as the following.
params.name: params

params.description: Struct containing query options, all cfquery tag attributes are supported except the name attribute.
params.name: options

examples.title: Simple Example
examples.description: SQL Only Example. Assums that a default datasource has been specified (by setting the variable this.datasource in Application.cfc)

examples.title: Passing Query Parameters using Struct
examples.description: Use :structKeyName in your sql then pass a struct with corresponding key names.
examples.code: qryResult = queryExecute("SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE empid = :empid AND country = :country", {country="USA", empid=1});

examples.title: Passing Query Parameters using Array
examples.description: When passing with an array use the ? as a placeholder in your sql
examples.code: qryResult = queryExecute("SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE empid = ? AND country = ?", [1,"USA"]);

examples.title: Passing Query Parameters using Struct of Structs
examples.description: If you need to pass the cfsqltype or other cfqueryparam attributes you can pass a struct for each param.
examples.code: qryResult = queryExecute("SELECT * FROM Employees WHERE empid = :empid AND country = :country", {country={value="USA", cfsqltype="cf_sql_varchar"}, empid={value=1, cfsqltype="cf_sql_integer"}});

examples.title: Specifying the Datasource
examples.description: If you have not defined the datasource using this.datasource in Application.cfc or want to explicitly specify the datasource use the third argument.

examples.title: IN Query using lists
examples.description: Query the database using a list of values
examples.code:
keys = '1,2,3,4,5,6,7';
data = queryExecute("select * from sometable where somecolumn in (:keys)",{keys={value=keys,list=true}});

examples.title: Query of Queries
examples.description: Query a local database variable without going through your database
